page.title: 13CHIPSTABLE VICAR INTERVIEWED
page.content: We went to the Vicarage at Chipstable, to talk to Mr Balchin, the rector of the combined parishes of Chipstable, Raddington, Huish Champflower and Clatworthy. On a typical Sunday, the parish priest might take a service at eight thirty in Chipstable church, another at Clatworthy church at ten, a third at Huish at eleven o'clock and then on to Raddington for a service at three. There are not many baptisms, or weddings in the Chipstable group of churches, in all about four of each a year. In fact the last wedding held in Raddington Church, about four years ago, was the first for thirteen years. Mr Balchin said that the nice thing about being a country parson is that the vicar knows everybody in the parish, and they all know him. There were no holiday homes, or commuters.
